column1: Which of the following statements regarding the Z-discs is correct?
column3: They are located in all types of muscle cells
column4: They are composed of actin and myosin
column5: They do not bind to myosin filaments
column6: They can be located only at the edges of cardiomyocytes
column8: Z-discs anchor thin (actin) filaments via alpha-actinin in striated muscle. Smooth muscle has dense bodies, not Z-discs.

column1: Which of the following statements regarding the red muscle fibers is NOT correct?
column8: Red (type I) fibers are slow oxidative, rich in myoglobin and mitochondria, use lipids, relatively less glycogen.

column1: What is the average lifespan of lymphocytes?
column2: from a few hours to a few decades
column8: Lymphocyte lifespan is highly variable, short-lived effectors to long-lived memory cells (years/decades).

column1: Which of the answers regarding the stratified epithelium is true?
column2: None of the answers are true
column8: Stratified epithelium includes keratinized, non-keratinized, and transitional (urothelium), so “only” statements are false.

column1: How many lobules can we typically find in a neutrophilic granulocyte?
column8: Mature neutrophils typically have a segmented nucleus with 3–5 lobes.

column1: Hyaline cartilage is present in the listed structures except for:
column8: Epiglottis is elastic cartilage. The others are classic hyaline cartilage locations.

column1: Identify the tissue shown on the picture:
column2: Complex tubuloacinar seromucous gland: serous, mucous and mixed secretory units.
column3: Transverse section of smooth muscle cells in a small intestine.
column4: Simple tubular mucous glands in large intestine.
column5: Endocrine epithelium in the form of follicles – thyroid gland.
column8: Follicles filled with eosinophilic colloid lined by simple cuboidal epithelium indicate thyroid gland.
Monocyte shows large size, kidney-shaped nucleus, abundant cytoplasm (TEM features).
Peripheral smear cell with kidney-shaped nucleus and abundant gray-blue cytoplasm is a monocyte.

column1: Caveolae are involved in all of the following EXCEPT:
column8: Caveolae are membrane microdomains for endocytosis/trafficking/signaling; ATP synthesis is mitochondrial.

column1: Which of the following proteins is associated with plasmalemmal stability:
column8: Spectrin forms a submembranous cytoskeletal network stabilizing the plasma membrane (classic in RBCs).

column1: Which of the following cytoskeletal elements is important for the nucleus:
column8: Nuclear lamina is composed of lamins (intermediate filaments), providing nuclear structural support.

column1: A genetic defect in the motor protein DYNEIN is linked to which of the following disorders?
column6: None of the answers is correct
column8: Dynein arm defect causes primary ciliary dyskinesia (Kartagener: chronic infections, situs inversus, infertility).

column1: Match each tissue to the characteristic structure: (1) Covering epithelium (2) Cardiac muscle tissue (3) Nerve tissue (4) Glandular epithelium (5) Bone tissue
column8: Correct mapping: covering epithelium→mesothelium, cardiac muscle→myocardium, nerve→synapse, glandular epithelium→islet of Langerhans, bone→osteon.

column1: From the 3rd month, the hemopoiesis is:
column8: From ~3rd month, fetal liver hematopoiesis is extravascular (cells form in tissue then enter blood).

column1: Which of the processes listed is NOT a stage of the fertilization?
column8: Gastrulation is week 3 germ-layer formation, not part of fertilization.

column1: The following structures are NOT derived from the endoderm:
column8: All listed structures are not endoderm-derived (bone/muscle/heart-vessels = mesoderm; nervous system = ectoderm).

column1: Which effect have prostaglandins of the semen?
column2: They reduce viscosity of cervical mucus, making it easier for sperm to travel up cervical canal into uterus
column3: They are hydrolytic enzymes that invade the endometrium
column4: They stimulate peristaltic contractions of female reproductive tract
column8: Semen prostaglandins facilitate sperm transport by thinning cervical mucus and stimulating uterine/tubal contractions.

column1: How does the female reproductive tract assist sperm migration?
column3: by uterine contractions during orgasm and strands of cervical mucus
column4: by a chemical secreted by the egg
column8: Sperm transport is helped by uterine contractions + favorable cervical mucus, and chemotactic signaling near the oocyte (B + C).
